values.alignmentText: Shanghai's riverfront promenades and pocket parks soften the dense skyline, yet industrial runoff and urban heat islands mean we seek weekend getaways for clean air.
A low-lying delta city, Shanghai faces typhoon storm surges and rising sea levels, though massive seawalls and drainage upgrades mitigate day-to-day risk.
Humid summers and damp winters require dehumidifiers and layered clothing, but spring and autumn offer pleasant windows for exploring neighborhoods.
Annual PM2.5 averages around 30 µg/m³; winter coal use and regional smog demand indoor purifiers and AQI tracking before outdoor play.
Typhoons and Yangtze flooding pose the biggest threats; earthquakes are rare but we still follow emergency prep guidance.
March warms from 10 °C (50 °F) to April-May highs near 22 °C (72 °F) with frequent rain and humidity.
June–August regularly hit 32–35 °C (90–95 °F) with high humidity and tropical nights, so reliable A/C and siesta scheduling are essential.
September stays warm around 28 °C (82 °F) before easing into crisp, sunny October days near 20 °C (68 °F).
December–February hover around 3–9 °C (37–48 °F); damp chill without central heating in older flats means we invest in space heaters.
Nearby beaches like Jinshan are swimmable but often murky; expats prefer day trips to Zhoushan or Hainan flights for clearer water.
Warm in the south but limited swim quality elsewhere.
City parks are manicured; true nature requires high-speed rail trips to Huangshan or Moganshan mountain retreats.
Shanghai's monthly minimum wage reached ¥2,690 in 2024—strong for China but modest once rent and schooling are included.
Senior engineers earn ¥350k–¥500k (~$48k–$68k) plus bonuses, comfortable locally but lower than Western packages.
Finance and manufacturing firms maintain .NET stacks, yet Mandarin fluency and long office hours narrow Trey's entry points.
Ruby remains niche; Sarah would rely on multinational teams or remote work to use her stack.
Class A/B work permits require degree, experience, and clean police checks; tech firms sponsor sparingly given quota scrutiny.
Large economy with high growth yet debt concerns.
Shanghai tech largely expects office-first presence, with only multinational hubs allowing sustained hybrid schedules.
Long hours culture such as 996 in tech.
Often exceed statutory 40 hours with overtime.
Five days after first year increasing with tenure.
Many workers take little time off.
Shanghai moves fast—late-night deliveries, crowded metros, and intense school culture mean we'd need to carve out slower routines intentionally.
International schools run 08:00–15:30; many tech offices expect 09:30–19:00 with overtime, so we'd lean on ayi support or staggered shifts.
Weekends: parks, malls, dining, family visits; extracurriculars common; some sectors work Saturdays; long retail hours in large cities.
Strong family obligations and multigenerational households.
Socially unacceptable with potential legal risks.
High academic pressure and competitiveness.
Infrastructure varies; urban parks limited.
Public schools intense; international schools costly but available.
Public kindergartens and private centers; supply/cost vary by city tier; expanding 0–3 services; waitlists in core districts.
Shanghai residents access longer maternity leave and monthly child stipends, yet slots in quality kindergartens remain competitive.
Expats rarely qualify for subsidies or public kindergarten without Shanghai hukou, pushing families toward costly international preschools.
Public schools broadly available but admissions tied to hukou/residence; quality varies; academic load often heavy.
Foreign dependents often steered to international schools (higher tuition); some cities allow public enrolment with conditions.
International/private schools in major cities (IB/AP/A-Levels); high fees and limited seats; admissions selective.
Maternity/paternity leave expanding; local cash/childcare incentives; housing/tax perks in some cities; coverage uneven.
Benefits generally tied to hukou/social insurance; foreign residents often ineligible for local family subsidies.
Extensive public HE; competitive gaokao; tuition moderate; scholarships and aid exist.
International student options widely available; tuition higher; scholarships exist; residency status may improve options.
Traditional roles prevalent especially outside cities.
Limited acceptance and no legal recognition.
Legal equality on paper but gaps in practice.
Emphasis on appearance and family roles.
Expectation of long work hours and provider role.
Ancient culture and rapid modernization.
Mandarin is essential for schooling, healthcare, and paperwork; English support exists only in expat enclaves of Shanghai and Shenzhen.
Party ideology prioritizes social harmony over individual rights, curbing feminist, queer, and labor activism.
Official ideology influences rhetoric and education.
High official atheism though traditional religions persist.
Public conservatism and limited sex education.
Pride events are regularly shut down and censorship targets queer media, so openly poly/LGBTQ+ families face persistent state pressure despite decriminalization.
Strong local networks yet wary of outsiders.
Proud of history and national resurgence.
Varies with regional rivalries and disputes.

values.key: View of Them by Neighboring Countries
values.alignmentText: Often seen as assertive or domineering.
Vibrant in tier‑1 cities (bars, clubs, live music); quieter elsewhere; closing times and enforcement vary by locality.
Urban streetwear and smart‑casual tailoring; sneakers/athleisure common; techwear influences in big cities.
Contemporary street style to minimalist chic; dresses/skirts with layering; strong beauty/skin‑care culture.
Mahjong, karaoke, and mobile gaming.
Niche but growing in urban hubs.
Bund rooftops, jazz clubs, and underground electronic scenes keep nightlife lively, though events operate within licensing and censorship limits.
Expanding tech meetups though gatherings are regulated.
Local escapes are mostly curated gardens; genuine wilderness requires train trips to Anhui or Zhejiang provinces.
One-party socialist state with centralized control.
State atheism; religion tightly regulated.
Unions are state-run with limited protections.
Socialism with Chinese characteristics guides policy.
The one-party system deploys surveillance, censorship, and security laws that leave no space for dissent, representing the lowest possible score for democratic resilience.
State-guided market economy.
Political stability high but dissent suppressed.
State media strongly shapes narratives.
Promotes unity and party achievements.
Limited rights for dissenting groups.
Official surveys show high trust; dissent is suppressed.
Anti-corruption campaigns ongoing yet local corruption persists.
Both petty and grand corruption, especially locally.
Three-bedroom apartments in central districts exceed ¥25,000/month and require agency fees, so many expats choose Pudong or suburban compounds for space.
Street crime stays low thanks to dense policing, though digital surveillance and internet controls remain pervasive.
Public system improving but uneven quality.
Private insurance often required for expats.
Public nurseries are limited, private centers are costly, and most families rely on grandparents or nannies to cover long work hours.
State encourages two-child families after relaxing policy.
Flagship schools deliver elite math and science results, yet gaokao pressure, censorship in curricula, and limited progressive pedagogy clash with the family’s priorities.
A 20-line metro, high-speed rail links, and ubiquitous mobile payments make car-free life effortless once we adapt to health-code style tracking.
State capitalism with market reforms.
Withholding with annual self-report; complex for expats.
Moderate personal taxes with social contributions.
Advanced mobile payments and cashless society.
Local food and transit are affordable, but international school tuition and imported groceries push overall budgets high for foreign families.
Urban employee basic pension plus enterprise/individual pillars; adequacy varies by region; reforms underway.
Participation depends on city/employer; some contributions refundable on exit; portability limited.
Z visas demand employer sponsorship, background checks, and health exams; entrepreneur or talent visas target high-investment applicants and are rarely approved.
Hospitality at the neighborhood level coexists with rising geopolitical suspicion; regular visa renewals face tighter scrutiny for US citizens.
Z visas convert to 1-year residence permits renewed annually; green cards are rare and require high investment or state sponsorship.
Naturalization is rare and restrictive.
Dependent visas allowed but with restrictions.
Processing can be lengthy with heavy paperwork.
Police registrations, exit permits for kids, and Great Firewall compliance are enforced rigorously; policy shifts can void visas with little notice.
No—dual nationality is not recognized; naturalization typically requires renouncing prior citizenship.
Residence/work permits tied to employer or category; local registration needed for banking/housing; healthcare insurance; internet controls (VPN use).
Tencent, NetEase, miHoYo, and Lilith maintain large Shanghai studios with heavy demand for engineers, albeit with rigorous hours.
Shanghai hosts miHoYo (Genshin Impact), Lilith Games, and Perfect World teams, keeping Trey's network near global hits.
Government-supported incubators and conferences exist.
Government incubators in Zhangjiang Hi-Tech Park and publisher investment exist, but approvals and content regulation slow indie launches.
Maglev trains, cashless payments, and smart city sensors make Shanghai feel ultramodern, even if controls come with that convenience.

Every season brings common extremes, so we rely on specialized clothing, cooling, or heating solutions to stay comfortable. Seasonal Weather at 5/10 and Natural Disasters at 4/10 steer the family toward a mixed outlook for seasonal extremes & variability.

Major daylight imbalances demand heavy interventions—SAD lamps, vitamin regimens, and frequent travel for sun exposure. Seasonal Weather at 5/10 and Environment at 4/10 steer the family toward a mixed outlook for seasonal sunlight hours.

Pleasant stretches appear sporadically, so spontaneous outdoor plans are rare and weather dominates scheduling. Seasonal Weather at 5/10 and Environment at 4/10 steer the family toward a mixed outlook for pleasant weather windows.

Families regularly compromise on safety or overcrowd to stay housed; civic support is patchy. Minimum Wage at 4/10, Housing Situation at 3/10, and Childcare Support (Citizens) at 5/10 steer the family toward a challenging outlook for quality of life – lower-income tier.

Lifestyle feels brittle; one unexpected expense forces significant cutbacks or debt. Typical Software Salaries at 6/10, Housing Situation at 3/10, and Work-Life Balance at 2/10 steer the family toward a challenging outlook for quality of life – middle-income tier.

Luxury services are thin; wealth management and elite schooling often require another city. Housing Situation at 3/10, Private Education at 5/10, and Family Life at 6/10 steer the family toward a challenging outlook for quality of life – higher-income tier.

values.key: Spacious Housing Benchmark (2k sq ft Rent)
values.alignmentText: Spacious rentals are rare; we likely settle for smaller homes or relocate to a different metro. Housing Situation at 3/10 and Cost of Living (Optional) at 4/10 steer the family toward a challenging outlook for spacious housing benchmark (2k sq ft rent).

Only experimental or short-term arrangements pop up, offering little stability for families. Community Vibes at 4/10, Meetups & Communities at 4/10, and Family Life at 6/10 steer the family toward a mixed outlook for community living opportunities.

Neighbors keep to themselves and rarely volunteer help; we lean heavily on external networks. Community Vibes at 4/10, Meetups & Communities at 4/10, and Common Hobbies at 5/10 steer the family toward a challenging outlook for friendliness & neighborliness index.

Harassment and exclusionary politics pose safety and stability risks. Welcoming of US Migrants at 2/10, Progressivism at 2/10, and Language & English Ubiquity at 2/10 steer the family toward an unsustainable outlook for immigrant sentiment – general.

Hostility or exclusionary policies make us feel unwelcome despite best efforts. Welcoming of US Migrants at 2/10, Language & English Ubiquity at 2/10, and View of Them by Neighboring Countries at 3/10 steer the family toward an unsustainable outlook for immigrant sentiment – white migrants.

Service norms are pragmatic; smiles and chit-chat are rare outside personal networks. Community Vibes at 4/10, Nightlife Culture at 6/10, and Common Hobbies at 5/10 steer the family toward a mixed outlook for surface interaction norms.

Depth is limited—most locals keep emotional distance except with lifelong friends. Community Vibes at 4/10, Meetups & Communities at 4/10, and What Is Intriguing at 7/10 steer the family toward a mixed outlook for depth-seeking social norms.

Touchy or crowded norms are common and require constant boundary setting. Community Vibes at 4/10, Sex (Attitudes) at 3/10, and View of self at 7/10 steer the family toward a mixed outlook for personal boundary & bubble norms.

Speaking openly risks social penalties, so most issues stay hidden. Progressivism at 2/10, What Is Intriguing at 7/10, and Trust in Government at 5/10 steer the family toward a challenging outlook for moral, honesty & openness expectations.

Noticeable emphasis on grooming means we budget extra time and money to fit in. Fashion Trends (Male) at 6/10 and Fashion Trends (Female) at 6/10 steer the family toward a mixed outlook for grooming & beauty investment.

Visible pressure to stay slim or athletic influences work and school culture. Fashion Trends (Male) at 6/10, Fashion Trends (Female) at 6/10, and Sex (Attitudes) at 3/10 steer the family toward a mixed outlook for body image & fitness pressure.

Fashionable appearance is expected in many settings, adding planning time and costs. Fashion Trends (Male) at 6/10 and Fashion Trends (Female) at 6/10 steer the family toward a mixed outlook for fashion & style expectations.

Consent education is weak; unwanted advances occur regularly. Sex (Attitudes) at 3/10, LGBTQ+ Attitudes at 2/10, and Nightlife Culture at 6/10 steer the family toward a challenging outlook for flirting boundaries & consent culture.

Communities enforce strict gendered behavior with little tolerance for experimentation. Gender Roles at 3/10, Gender Fluidity at 1/10, and Sex (Attitudes) at 3/10 steer the family toward an unsustainable outlook for gendered flirting expectations.

Hostile policies or social norms make non-monogamy extremely risky. Polyamory at 1/10, Sex (Attitudes) at 3/10, and Community Vibes at 4/10 steer the family toward an unsustainable outlook for monogamy vs. non-monogamy acceptance.

Reputational risks exist, especially for women or queer folks discussing partners. Sex (Attitudes) at 3/10, Nightlife & Music at 8/10, and Community Vibes at 4/10 steer the family toward a mixed outlook for promiscuity attitudes.

Multi-partner households face outright hostility or legal barriers. Polyamory at 1/10, Community Vibes at 4/10, and LGBTQ+ Attitudes at 2/10 steer the family toward an unsustainable outlook for group & multi-partner relationship attitudes.

Physical proximity is unavoidable in many settings with limited accommodations. Community Vibes at 4/10, Sex (Attitudes) at 3/10, and Nightlife Culture at 6/10 steer the family toward a challenging outlook for personal space & touch norms.

Permissive laws and visible ownership prompt caution in public spaces. Safety & Crime at 7/10, State Ideology at 5/10, and Political System at 1/10 steer the family toward a mixed outlook for firearm laws & ownership culture.

Harsh sentencing and moral panic dominate political rhetoric. Progressivism at 2/10, Political System at 1/10, and Safety & Crime at 7/10 steer the family toward a challenging outlook for controlled substance policies.

Aggressive tactics and profiling are common, eroding trust in authorities. Safety & Crime at 7/10, Progressivism at 2/10, and Authoritarian Backsliding Risk at 1/10 steer the family toward a challenging outlook for drug enforcement climate.
Multiple incidents within the past decade impact how we choose schools and venues. Safety & Crime at 7/10 and Stability at 5/10 steer the family toward a mixed outlook for mass violence incidence.

Abuses are common and reforms stall; immigrants risk severe treatment if detained. Authoritarian Backsliding Risk at 1/10, Safety & Crime at 7/10, and Perceived Corruption at 4/10 steer the family toward a challenging outlook for carceral conditions & prison labor.

Infrastructure is inconsistent; safe walking requires choosing specific neighborhoods. Public Transportation at 10/10, Housing Situation at 3/10, and Nature Access at 5/10 steer the family toward a mixed outlook for walkability & pedestrian safety.

Community norms lean unhealthy, making it hard to model good habits for kids. Healthcare (Citizens) at 5/10, Work-Life Balance at 2/10, and Community Vibes at 4/10 steer the family toward a challenging outlook for community health consciousness.

Maintaining clean eating requires vigilance and possibly specialty stores. Cost of Living (Optional) at 4/10, Community Health Consciousness at 4/10, and Fresh & International Cuisine Access at 6/10 steer the family toward a mixed outlook for processed food saturation.

Fresh options exist yet international diversity is limited to a few neighborhoods. Nightlife & Music at 8/10, Common Hobbies at 5/10, and Meetups & Communities at 4/10 steer the family toward a mixed outlook for fresh & international cuisine access.

Prevalence is high with long waits and patchy insurance coverage. Seasonal Weather at 5/10, Work-Life Balance at 2/10, and Community Vibes at 4/10 steer the family toward a challenging outlook for depression prevalence.

Chronic disease linked to obesity burdens healthcare systems noticeably. Community Health Consciousness at 4/10, Work-Life Balance at 2/10, and Cost of Living (Optional) at 4/10 steer the family toward a challenging outlook for obesity rate.

Incidence trends upward; access to specialized care may be strained. Environment at 4/10, Healthcare (Citizens) at 5/10, and Community Health Consciousness at 4/10 steer the family toward a challenging outlook for cancer incidence.

Economic cycles bring recurring layoffs; we keep emergency funds and remote options ready. Economic Health at 6/10, Remote-Friendly Culture at 3/10, and Typical Software Salaries at 6/10 steer the family toward a mixed outlook for broader job market resilience.
